Dear Mr. Williams:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 2/25/2022.
An Exit was held on 3/4/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections
of the contract and MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of 11 new employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s six months evaluation due by 11/10/2021 was
completed late on 1/28/2022.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One eight open foster home records reviewed showed the foster
parents’ first aid certifications expired 9/25/2021 and 10/12/2021
respectively. An updated certification had not been obtained.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the information required by (c)-(f) was
provided to the child’s relative at placement.
4

R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(a): One of three initial service plan (ISP) reviewed were six
days late. This case was for an independent living youth’s
record.
Repeat Violation-Renewal December 2021 cite under
R400.12509 (3)(0).
(b): Three of 24 updated services plans (USP) reviewed were
late by:
 One day.
 Six days.
 Nine days. late.
Two of these USPs were for independent youth records.
Repeat Violation- Renewal December 2020- cite under
R400.12418 and R400.12509(3)(o).
R400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R400.12418(2)(a)
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as required
under R400.12404(4).
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
5

ISEP 6.19 (5) (c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the child(ren),
if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
Three of 27 service plans reviewed did not show documentation
of the youth’s signature.
Six of 27 service plans reviewed did not show documentation of
the birth parent’s signature.
Repeat Violation-Renewal December 2020-cited under FOM
722-8C.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Eight of 27 service plans (for six open foster child records)
reviewed did not show compliance:
 Two records did not show documentation of the
caregiver’s signature on the Parent Agency Treatment
Plan Agreement (PATPA) for the respective child’s ISP.
 A third record did not show documentation of the

 A fourth record did not show documentation of the

FOM 722-08 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
Completion Requirements:
8

The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
 Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program case closure.
Three of eight closed child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One child’s record did not show documentation of a DHS-
69 for the child’s 12/7/2021 case closure from the
agency.
 A second and third child’s record showed the DHS-69
was completed more than three business days after the
respective child’s 1/7/2021 and 11/8/2021 case closure
date. The former DHS-69 was dated 1/28/2021; and the
latter DHS-69 was dated 11/24/2021.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
Five of eight open foster child record reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of a quarterly
medical passport for the period 5/2/2021-7/30/2021.
 Four others did not show consistent documentation that
the medical passport was provided to the caregiver
quarterly.
Repeat Violation- Renewal December 2020.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12209(1) Orientation and training.
9

 The agency was apprised it shall clearly and accurately show
documentation of the social worker’s/supervisor’s completion of the 16
hours this rule requires, so that it does not show all were completed in one
day.
R400.12510(1)(d) Independent living record.
 The agency was apprised its youth’s independent living contract shall
consistently document the location where the youth is living.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12212(2)(d) Personnel records.
 The agency was advised ensuring that new hire references are not over
one year old at the time of hire would be of best practice.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to an allegation that the foster parent will spank the child when
the child gets in trouble. The foster parent admitted to the allegation and was found
in violation of the behavior management rule. The agency developed a corrective
action plan with the foster parent.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection where it
received the following violations:
 R400.12325(3)(b) for License recommendation.
 R400.12327(7) for Special evaluation.
 R400.12418(2)(b) for Development of service plans
 R400.12509(3)(o) for independent living record.
 FOM 722-06B for Family Team Meeting.
 FOM 722-8C for PATPA signatures.
 FOM 722-09 for Supervisory approval of service plans.
 FOM 801 for Medical Passports.
 FOM 722-07F for Permanency Plan Approval Packet.
 ADM 300 for Child Adoption Assessment.
10

The agency made progress with the corrective plan but were not completely
successful. They received repeat violations as indicated in this report.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts indicated this inspection.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the agency continue on a
regular license.
